title: Fierce and Unpredictable: How Wildfires Became Infernos
abstract: A division of the U.S. Forest Service is studying fire behavior as the blazes in the West become hotter and spread faster than ever before.

title: The ‘Zombie Gene’ That May Protect Elephants From Cancer
abstract: With such enormous bodies, elephants should be particularly prone to tumors. But an ancient gene in their DNA, somehow resurrected, seems to shield the animals.

title: Maria Konnikova Shows Her Cards
abstract: The well-regarded science writer took up poker while researching a book. Now she’s on the professional circuit.

title: Parker Solar Probe Launches on NASA Voyage to ‘Touch the Sun’
abstract: The spacecraft, which NASA says will “touch the sun,” was carried from the launchpad atop three columns of flame early on Sunday morning.

title: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Is Named for Him. 60 Years Ago, No One Believed His Ideas About the Sun.
abstract: Eugene N. Parker predicted the existence of solar wind in 1958. The NASA spacecraft is the first named for a living person.

title: Friendly Foxes’ Genes Offer Hints to How Dogs Became Domesticated
abstract: A long-running experiment provides clues to genes that influence friendliness to humans.

title: Fossils on an Australian Beach Reveal a Shark-Eat-Shark World
abstract: An amateur fossil hunter at first found a single shark tooth. It led to signs of a prehistoric shark feast.

title: Give a Cow a Brush, and Watch It Scratch That Itch
abstract: Some researchers think mechanical brushes aren’t just some spa amenity for dairy cows — they’re important to the animal’s well-being.

title: Something Digs Intricate Tunnels in Garnets. Is It Alive?
abstract: The deep red gems have long been found marred with internal markings. Researchers propose a new explanation involving fungal microorganisms who have found a nice place to live.

title: Review: Looking to the Stars, ‘Cielo’ Can’t Quite Form a Constellation
abstract: Alison McAlpine’s experimental feature tries to film an essentially unfilmable subject: the night sky above the Atacama Desert in Chile.

title: The Scientist Who Scrambled Darwin’s Tree of Life
abstract: How the microbiologist Carl Woese fundamentally changed the way we think about evolution and the origins of life.

title: With Short, Intense Sessions, Some Patients Finish Therapy in Just Weeks
abstract: The new psychological approach targets anxiety, PTSD and other mental disorders. Fewer people drop out with short-term treatment, and relief is quicker.

title: Clues to Your Health Are Hidden at 6.6 Million Spots in Your DNA
abstract: With a sophisticated new algorithm, scientists have found a way to forecast an individual’s risks for five deadly diseases.

title: They Thought Hemophilia Was a ‘Lifelong Thing.’ They May Be Wrong.
abstract: Experimental gene therapies have yielded promising results in early trials. But the drugs have left some patients wary, worried that success will not last.

title: U.S. Ambassador Denies Threatening Ecuador Over Breast-Feeding Resolution
abstract: Ambassador Todd C. Chapman said that allegations he pressured the country by threatening trade sanctions and withdrawal of military aid were “patently false.”

title: Amid Europe’s Heat Wave, Rare Flamingos Lay First Eggs in 15 Years
abstract: The eggs weren’t viable, but officials at a wildlife reserve in Britain gave the tropical birds chicks from a related species to raise as their own.

title: A Box Fell From the Sky. It Had a Note About Trump. The Police Were Not Amused.
abstract: The package landed on a New Jersey field with a note assuring that the device was not a bomb and wishing the president a “great round of golf.”

title: NASA Delays Parker Solar Probe Launch
abstract: There’s a lot we don’t know about the sun and its power, and this mission will help to fill in the blanks in the years to come. A second launch attempt on Sunday is possible.

title: As Catholic Hospitals Expand, So Do Limits on Some Procedures
abstract: Many religious health care institutions do not make it clear up front what procedures they won’t perform, a New York Times analysis shows.

title: E.P.A. Staff Objected to Agency’s New Rules on Asbestos Use, Internal Emails Show
abstract: The clash over the proposal exposes the tensions within the E.P.A. over the Trump administration’s efforts to roll back environmental regulations.

title: Meet Iceland’s Whaling Magnate. He Makes No Apologies.
abstract: Kristjan Loftsson’s company is the last one in the world still hunting fin whales. His credo: “If it’s sustainable, you hunt.”

title: Court Orders E.P.A. to Ban Chlorpyrifos, Pesticide Tied to Children’s Health Problems
abstract: The ruling by a federal appeals court was a major setback for the pesticide industry, which had successfully lobbied the Trump administration to reject a ban.

title: Pence Advances Plan to Create a Space Force
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence gave details about President Trump’s plan to create a military force for space. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis is now onboard with the plan.

title: Marine Mammals Have Lost a Gene That Now They May Desperately Need
abstract: Dolphins, manatees, sea lions, elephant seals and other animals no longer produce an enzyme that protects land mammals against harmful chemicals, including some pesticides.

title: 2018 Is Shaping Up to Be the Fourth-Hottest Year. Yet We’re Still Not Prepared for Global Warming.
abstract: It’s hot. But it may not be the new normal yet. Temperatures are still rising.

title: Psychologists’ Group Maintains Ban on Work at Military Detention Facilities
abstract: Members of the American Psychological Association voted against allowing psychologists to resume work at certain detention centers like the one in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Asbestos in a Crayon, Benzene in a Marker: A School Supply Study’s Toxic Results
abstract: A public interest group tested 27 back-to-school products and found dangerous chemicals in four of them.

title: Alan Rabinowitz, Conservationist of Wild Cats, Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. Rabinowitz made it his life’s mission to preserve lions, tigers, leopards and cheetahs after childhood encounters with a jaguar at the Bronx Zoo

title: A ‘Generationally Perpetuated’ Pattern: Daughters Do More Chores
abstract: They also earn less allowance, suggesting that the gender inequality in pay begins at home, and early in life. But there are signs the gap is narrowing.

title: Tornadoes on the East Coast May Be a Sign of Things to Come
abstract: Is climate change making tornadoes more common in places where they once were infrequent?
